bibl.title: Letter from Mrs. George Carroll to Philip Showalter Hench, May 2, 1956

div1.p: Mrs. Carroll claims that Hench never returned the papers she loaned to him two years ago. She has lost all interest in the Carroll affair and does not wish to have further contact with Hench regarding the matter. She comments on the credit given to Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Mrs. George Carroll to Philip Showalter Hench, May 2, 1956
div1.p:
Just a few lines in reply to your letter of April 16th (unsigned) re-
questing permission to photostat certain papers in the Carroll collection
when you are in Washington in the near future.

The papers are not in my possession as I stored them for safe keeping
just before I entered the hospital last November as I did not know what might
happen. In looking over my correspondence with you, I find that you have
never returned the papers I loaned you when you were here February 19, 1954.
A later letter shows that you were having the photostatic work done and that
you would send the papers by registered mail. I trusted you with these papers
as I thought you would keep your word.

I do not want to be rude but I have lost all interest in the Carroll
affair because it is much too late to remedy the situation for all those most
interested have passed on. It is regrettable that Mother Carroll who knew
all the facts did not have some one write a book during her life-time. My
husband was ill for so long that he was not able to do so either. The two
remaining children were so young when their father died that they do not
remember many things. It has been Walter Reed's show all the way through,
partly because he was the commanding officer in charge at the time (who
always gets the credit) and partly because the Reed family promoted the
affair from every angle. I attended the affair at the Cuban Embassy in April
1954 and no sixteen year old girl ever acted so silly as Blossom Reed did
when the Cuban Ambassador presented the medal to her. I was thoroughly
disgusted.

Please return the papers I loaned you on February 19, 1954 as I loaned
them to you in good faith, then we can consider the matter closed. It is
immaterial to me whether Dr. Carroll gets credit due him at this late date
for what does it matter when all who would appreciate it are gone. After
all “the paths of glory lead but to the grave” and who cares about you or me or
any one after the last call is sounded.

I had the operation last November 16th and it was an ordeal. I got an
infection in left foot and suffered terribly. I was lame before the operation
and I am still lame. The only difference I can see is that I exchanged sharp
agonizing pains for weak tender feet. The metatarsal heads were removed
and as I said it was an ordeal. The operation lasted four hours and I was in
the hospital three weeks. When the main piors of a bridge are removed, you
have a weak structure which eventually collapses. That will probably be the
way with my feet but I was so miserable before that I decided to take a chance.
One cannot foresee the outcome but I refuse to worry for in the words of
Somerset Maugham “I have my suitcase packed and am waiting for the last train.”

Sorry I will not be able to help you and awaiting return of the papers I
loaned you, I am
